repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body: This PR is introducing pure python mode in Profiling tutorial. It is partial fix of #4187

+    val: cython.double = 0.

comment_data.body: To be honest, I prefer to have explicit `cython.double` here. Cython is automatically using `double` C type when variable is annotated by python `float` type. This can be confusing for the newcomers. I agree that it would look better but in tutorial I prefer to not introduce this hidden complexity.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,16 @@
+# cython: profile=True
+
+@cython.cfunc
+@cython.inline
+@cython.exceptval(-1.0)
+def recip_square(i: int) -> cython.double:

comment_data.body: done.

@@ -0,0 +1,16 @@

+def approx_pi(n: cython.int=10000000):
+    val: cython.double = 0.
+    k: cython.int
+    for k in range(1, n + 1):
+        val += recip_square(k)
+    return (6 * val) ** .5

+

comment_data.body:
It has already been used in docs in new pythonized versions, so you are not introducing anything here.

But look at it like this: you are seeing cython for the first time and you don’t know that behind the scenes python `float` is actually `double`, and this is where you get even more confused, for pythonista it is easier to use the already known `float`.
And there is no hiding here, it is nicely described [here](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/tutorial/pure.html#pep-484-type-annotations)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,16 @@
+# cython: profile=True
+
+@cython.cfunc
+@cython.inline
+@cython.exceptval(-1.0)
+def recip_square(i: int) -> cython.double:

comment_data.body:
I have found out that example currently present in master branch is failing with following error:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/matus/dev/cython/docs/examples/tutorial/profiling_tutorial/test/profile_2.py", line 8, in <module>
    cProfile.runctx("calc_pi.approx_pi()", globals(), locals(), "Profile.prof")
  File "/usr/lib/python3.9/cProfile.py", line 19, in runctx
    return _pyprofile._Utils(Profile).runctx(statement, globals, locals,
  File "/usr/lib/python3.9/profile.py", line 62, in runctx
    prof.runctx(statement, globals, locals)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.9/cProfile.py", line 100, in runctx
    exec(cmd, globals, locals)
  File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
  File "calc_pi.pyx", line 11, in calc_pi.approx_pi
    val += recip_square(k)
  File "calc_pi.pyx", line 5, in calc_pi.recip_square
    return 1. / (i * i)
ZeroDivisionError: float division
```

It seems that it is due overflow of `i * i` expression. Casting to `long` fixes the issue.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,14 @@
+# cython: profile=True
+
+@cython.cfunc
+@cython.inline
+@cython.exceptval(-1.0)
+def recip_square(i: cython.int) -> cython.double:
+    return 1. / (cython.cast(cython.long, i) * i)

comment_data.body:
1) can we cast whole `i*i` statement? it'll look better
2) then why not to use `long` instead of `int`?
3) can't we prevent passing such values that cause overflow? We are controlling them in `approx_pi` AFAIU
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,14 @@
+# cython: profile=True
+
+@cython.cfunc
+@cython.inline
+@cython.exceptval(-1.0)
+def recip_square(i: cython.int) -> cython.double:
+    return 1. / (cython.cast(cython.long, i) * i)

comment_data.body:
as I understand the only difference is .py / .pyx?
oh yes, as stated [here](https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/4311#issuecomment-887381089)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -209,20 +209,41 @@ We only added two lines, the rest stays completely the same. Alternatively, we c
 manually compile our code into an extension; we wouldn't need to change the
 profile script then at all. The script now outputs the following:
 
-.. code-block:: none
+.. tabs::
 
-   Sat Nov  7 18:02:33 2009    Profile.prof
+    .. group-tab:: Pure Python
 
-            10000004 function calls in 4.406 CPU seconds
+        .. code-block:: none
 
-      Ordered by: internal time

-      ncalls  tottime  percall  cumtime  percall filename:lineno(function)
-           1    3.305    3.305    4.406    4.406 calc_pi.pyx:7(approx_pi)
-    10000000    1.101    0.000    1.101    0.000 calc_pi.pyx:4(recip_square)
-           1    0.000    0.000    4.406    4.406 {calc_pi.approx_pi}
-           1    0.000    0.000    4.406    4.406 <string>:1(<module>)

+            10000000    1.101    0.000    1.101    0.000 calc_pi.py:3(recip_square)
+                   1    0.000    0.000    4.406    4.406 {calc_pi.approx_pi}
+                   1    0.000    0.000    4.406    4.406 <string>:1(<module>)
+                   1    0.000    0.000    0.000    0.000 {method 'disable' of '_lsprof.Profiler' objects}

+    .. group-tab:: Cython

comment_data.body:
> can we cast whole i*i statement? it'll look better
   
`cython.cast(cython.long, i * i))` does not work because it is yelding `(long) (i * i)` C code which is still crashing.

> then why not to use long instead of int?

I was thinking about that. For now I decided to leave example as close to original as possible (with `int` parameters of function). I leave on @scoder what is better

> can't we prevent passing such values that cause overflow? We are controlling them in approx_pi AFAIU

We can but the simple example is not doing that. I think the best is to keep it simple and just change type to long or cast it.

Not because of this line (that's just a comment for Python) but because it is used in the type declarations below.

commit.message: Avoid ZeroDivisionError in examples by casting to long
Change "int" to "long long" in the examples since that's what we need for the calculation.

Change "int" to "long long" in the examples since that's what we need for the calculation.

repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

milestone.description:
Goals:
– New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
– Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3`.
– Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
– Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Docs: Migrate profiling tutorial to pure python
